items.content_html:
Current support in Chrome 94 can be easily confirmed:
https://mdn-bcd-collector.appspot.com/tests/api/MediaStream/id
https://mdn-bcd-collector.appspot.com/tests/api/MediaStreamTrack/id

These were both introduced in WebKit trunk version 537.26:
https://trac.webkit.org/changeset/139352/webkit
https://trac.webkit.org/browser/webkit/trunk/Source/WebCore/Configurations/Version.xcconfig?rev=139352

That maps to Chrome 26, matching the existing version_added.

The original data here came from wiki migration:
#1212

The data for api.MediaStreamTrack also has to be updated to pass the
lint. Support for MediaStreamTrack in Chrome 26 can be confirmed with
this test:
http://software.hixie.ch/utilities/js/live-dom-viewer/?saved=9656

The interface object wasn't exposed in Chrome 26-28, which is the most
likely explanation for why support was set to 29 in this PR:
#5844

Don't both with partial_implementation and notes for this, since
there's no constructor and it doesn't really matter if the interface
object is exposed or not.
items.title: Fix support for MediaStream.id and MediaStreamTrack.id

items.content_html:
Support for Edge in 79 and later was missing, and the constructor entry
was also missing the prefixes.
items.title: Correctly represent support for webkitMediaStream

items.content_html:
Summary

This updates Firefox support data for the feature policy functionality.

Test results and supporting details

Tested on latest Firefox using https://demo.lukewarlow.uk/feature-policy/

https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1617219 - Shows it was enabled in 74

https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1483631 - Is what I've used to work out the initial values that were supported. Though I suspect others beyond the media and geolocation values were also supported.

Related issues

#12545
items.title: Update Firefox support for feature-policy

items.content_html: This is all standards track and no longer experimental.
items.title: Update statuses for devicemotion and deviceorientaton(absolute) events

items.content_html:
All of these entries are in at least 2 of Chrome, Firefox and Safari.

A few entries, like api.KeyframeEffect.iterationComposite, are left
untouched due to still being single-engine.
items.title: Mark Web Animations as no longer experimental

items.content_html:
This property is on GlobalEventHandlers in spec and BCD already, and
doesn't appear on either of the HTML*Element interfaces in the HTML
spec.

Note that "error_event" entries remain, and that does make sense since
the event being fired is separate from whether onerror exists.
items.title: Remove onerror properties for HTMLImageElement and HTMLMediaElement

items.content_html:
Summary

Adds browser support data for self.reportError(). Included a 404 mdn url on the assumption it will soon link to something. Happy to remove though.

Test results and supporting details

Firefox tracking bug: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1722448 - Milestone 93

Chrome feature status: https://www.chromestatus.com/feature/5634523220934656 - Milestone 95

Safari TP release notes: https://webkit.org/blog/11971/release-notes-for-safari-technology-preview-132/#:~:text=Implemented%20self.reportError()
items.title: Added self.reportError compat data.

items.content_html:
Summary

This PR updates support for the display-capture feature policy, to include Chrome and Edge 94.

Test results and supporting details

https://www.chromestatus.com/feature/5144822362931200 - Shows this is enabled in Desktop 94.
items.title: Set Chrome 94 as supporting `display-capture` feature policy

items.content_html:

Test results and supporting details

https://chromereleases.googleblog.com/2021/09/stable-channel-update-for-desktop_21.html

https://chromereleases.googleblog.com/2021/09/chrome-for-android-update_21.html

https://www.chromestatus.com/features/schedule - for the Chrome 95, and 96 release dates.
items.title: Set Chrome 94 as current

items.content_html:
Summary

Add compatibility data for WebExtension Commands API callback arguments. Specifically, this adds the second tab argument. onCommand.name.__compat is taken from onCommand.__compat.

Test results and supporting details

Chromium docs showing "Chrome 86+" next to tabs.

Related issues
items.title: Add webextensions.onCommand.tab

items.content_html: For mdn/content#9098
items.title: Prototype single entry for media element volumechange event

items.content_html:
Summary

This PR adds Deno version data for Object.assign JS builtin

Test results and supporting details

Downgrade deno to v1.0 with the command deno upgrade --version 1.0.0, and you can check that Object.assign exists with the below commands:

$ deno --version
deno 1.0.0
v8 8.4.300
typescript 3.9.2
$ deno eval "console.log(Object.assign({foo: 1}, {bar: 2}))"
{ foo: 1, bar: 2 }
items.title: Add Deno data for Object.assign

items.content_html:
FF93 just added support for class static initialization blocks: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1725689 (actually they were present behind a preference in FF92, but I didn't know about that, and I'm not sure it's useful).

This is only present in FF93 right now. It is present in v8 engine from v9.4 and that will go into Chrome 94 - still in beta. So for now I have put those as false. I also tested this in nodejs using the latest NVM I can get v16.9.1 on Ubuntu and that says we're still at v8 engine 9.3.345.16-node.12.

Test code is just a block of javascript that either dumps output to console or gives me a syntax error:

class C {
  // This block will run when the class itself is evaluated
  static { 
    console.log("C's static block");
  }
}

Explainer on this feature here: https://v8.dev/features/class-static-initializer-blocks (MDN docs under construction)
items.title: JS class static inititialization blocks

items.content_html:
This adds Intl.getSupportedValuesOf() which was added to FF93 in https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1670033.
Docs work tracking in mdn/content#8618

I have tested and it is not in Chrome, which matches the tracking bug: https://bugs.chromium.org/p/v8/issues/detail?id=10743. I can't find evidence of it in Safari either (but have not tested).

NOTE, the spec this is in is at stage 3: https://github.com/tc39/proposal-intl-enumeration
The URL for the "proposal spec" is not allowed (https://tc39.es/proposal-intl-enumeration/#sec-intl.supportedvaluesof). What I have done is put in the spec URL where the record will eventually go .

Marked experimental as FF is currently only implementation.
items.title: Add Intl.getSupportedValuesOf()

items.content_html:
Summary

Added missing Support Information from Samsung Internet 16.0

Test results and supporting details

This is data from Chrome 91 that wasn't copied across when Samsung Internet 16 was originally added.
items.title: Missing Samsung Internet 16.0 support data

items.content_html:
Summary

This PR adds Safari 15 flag data. These are new (mostly) off by default flags that are added in Safari 15.

Test results and supporting details

This data comes from looking through the Experimental Features UI in Safari's interface (Settings -> Safari -> Advanced -> Experimental Features for iOS)
items.title: Add Safari 15 flag data

items.content_html:
This PR performs two actions related to the options for scroll, scrollTo, and scrollBy.

First, the ScrollToOptions dictionary is deleted, and its properties are converted into subfeatures of the dependent methods.

Second, this updates and corrects the data for these different options. While trying to fill out the real values for both Firefox and Safari, I noticed a few discrepancies with the Chrome data as well. This PR fixes them using the following commit/bug data:

  • options.left, options.top
    • Chrome: 41 - https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/8b3ec94a0d488e26d2854f6465480106487090d9
    • Firefox: 36 - https://bugzil.la/1045754
    • Safari: 10.1 (603.1.5) - https://trac.webkit.org/changeset/205505/webkit
  • options.behavior
    • Chrome: 35 - https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/d5703dc81f333467a9fd2b929ec56d1f8c2410ca
    • Firefox: 27 - https://bugzil.la/918345
    • Safari: 14 (610.1.1) - https://trac.webkit.org/browser/webkit/trunk/Source/WebKit/ChangeLog?rev=254790

Additionally, this removes the IE and Edge partial implementation block on api.Window.scrollBy describing that only scrollBy(x, y) is supported. This is referring to the lack of support for the options parameter, which is already taken care of by the subfeature.
items.title: Remove ScrollToOptions dictionary; fix scroll options data

items.content_html: I'm documenting @layer, this is the BCD. Currently, the Firefox implementation is behind a flag mdn/content#8999
items.title: Adding @layer

items.content_html:
background-attachment: fixed doesn't work since iOS 13, as you can verify using this simple test I wrote, or see in these links:

https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=196327
https://developer.apple.com/forums/thread/99883
items.title: css: bg-attachment: fixed not supported on iOS

items.content_html:
This was missed in #11518.

This is defined using WindowOrWorkerGlobalScope in the spec:
https://w3c.github.io/hr-time/#the-performance-attribute

None of the data was validated or changed, just moved.
items.title: Move the performance attribute to api.performance (in _globals)
